You will get better mileage passing a jar to addCrawlJob that contains 
your seeds and order rather than trying to pass them as individual 
arguments into JMX.  Looking at addCrawllJob seeds treatment, it looks 
like the seeds argument is actually dropped on certain code paths down 
through the addCrawlJob overrides (e.g. 
http://crawler.archive.org/xref/org/archive/crawler/Heritrix.html#1349).

Here is code for 'start': 
http://crawler.archive.org/xref/org/archive/crawler/Heritrix.html#1889.  
It puts an heritrix instance into a 'ready' mode such that if you give 
the instance a job, it'll start crawling it.  Clicking it, you should 
see a change in the Heritrix instance status message.

Creating a new instance is something else altogether.  You need to 
invoke an heritrix constructor.  I do not remember if this is possible 
from jconsole.  It is possible using the jmxclient-commandline tool: 
http://crawler.archive.org/cmdline-jmxclient/.

St.Ack


badswalu wrote:
>
> I was looking at a running instance of Heritrix with jconsole and
> playing around with the controls and had a few questions.
>
> Adding new jobs:
> When adding a job using the "addJob" or "addJobBasedOn" openMBeans, is
> it possible to add more than one URL? I noticed that the seeds
> attribute description says "Initial seed(s)". I have tried ways of
> entering multiple seeds through jconsole, and none have worked. I have
> tried separating the URLs with space, typing the newline escape char
> \n, typing the enter key (which just activated the action). Is there a
> limitation with jconsole's UI that makes it impossible to submit
> multiple seeds with a new job? i.e. Could i connect to Heritrix with
> JMX from my own app and pass a java string like
> "http://www.domain1.com 
> <http://www.domain1.com>\nhttp://www.domain2.com 
> <nhttp://www.domain2.com>\n ... " as the seed?
>
> Starting new instances:
> There is a button labeled start() in jconsole for Heritrix and has a
> description of "Start Heritrix instance". I have clicked this button
> expecting a new instance of Heritrix to be started, but nothing
> happens. Does this button do something else, or am I not using it
> right? I have started Heritrix on the command line. What steps have to
> be taken to make the start() method actually start a new instance of
> Heritrix through JMX?
>
> Thank you much,
> badswalu
>
>
